questions.question:
Question 1: Hematuria in children is defined as the presence of at least  
 RBCs per high power field 
in uncentrifuged urine.
questions.explanation:
511 
Sold by @itachibot Hematuria in children is defined as the presence of at least 5 RBCs/HPF (high power field) in 
uncentrifuged urine. When using commercially available dipsticks (capable of detecting 3-5 RBCs / HPF of urine), the 
presence of 10-50 RBCs/L suggests an underlying pathology. False-negative results can occur in the presence of • Formalin • High urinary concentrations of ascorbic acid False-positive results, on the other hand, may be seen • With alkaline urine (pH > 8) • Contamination with oxidizing agents such as hydrogen peroxide (used to clean the perineum 
before obtaining a specimen)

questions.question:
Question 2: An 11-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of multiple 
episodes of passing blood in the urine. Which of the following condition is not associated with 
this symptom?
questions.explanation:
Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) presents with acute-onset microscopic hematuria not 
recurrent gross hematuria. Causes of recurrent gross hematuria: • Alport’s syndrome: hereditary nephritis • Thin glomerular basement membrane disease • IgA nephropathy: Berger’s disease • Idiopathic hypercalciuria/hyperuricosuria • Sickle cell nephropathy (papillary necrosis)

questions.question:
Question 3: A 6-year-old girl with urinary complaints was brought to the hospital by her parents. On 
further enquiry, they mention a history of skin lesions 5 weeks back. Low C3 levels are found 
during her investigations. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals a “lumpy-bumpy” pattern 
of immunoglobulin and complement deposits on the glomerular basement membrane. Which 
of the following is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Urinary complaints with a history of skin lesions (pyoderma) point towards a likely diagnosis of 
glomerulonephritis. Results of complement study and immunofluorescence microscopy also 
correlate with this diagnosis. Frothy urine is due to proteinuria, which is a feature of nephrotic 
syndrome. Classic features of nephritic syndrome/glomerulonephritis: • Cola coloured urine (hematuria) • Oliguria • Hypertension • Facial or body edema 512 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: Akshay, accompanied by his father, presents to the OPD with complaints of cola-coloured 
urine and facial puffiness for 3 days. He has a history of fever with a sore throat that resolved 
2 weeks back. Which of the following findings is consistent with the diagnosis of 
post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?

options.a: C3 level increases and ASO level increases
options.b: C3 level decreases and ASO level increases
options.c: C3 level decreases and ASO level decreases
options.d: C3 level increases and ASO level decreases

questions.explanation:
C3 level decreases and ASO level increases in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Acute PSGN is a classic example of an acute nephritic syndrome characterized by the sudden 
onset of gross hematuria, oedema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It follows infection of the 
throat or skin by certain nephritogenic strains of group A -hemolytic streptococci- • 1 to 2 weeks after an antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hematuria associated with 
glomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation:
Hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis is typically painless. Hematuria from within the glomerulus is often associated with brown-, cola-, or tea-colored urine. 
Urine analysis reveals RBC casts and deformed urinary RBCs (particularly acanthocytes).

questions.question:
Question 6: A 7-year-old boy presents with decreased urine output for 3 days. He has a history of sore 
throat 2 weeks back. On examination, he is hypertensive with pitting pedal oedema. The 
diagnosis is concluded as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is 
true about this condition?

options.d: Renal biopsy is indicated in severe impairment of renal function.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette of oliguria, pedal edema and hypertension point towards 
glomerulonephritis. Severe impairment of renal functions in a background of post-streptococcal 
glomerulonephritis is an indication for renal biopsy. Indications for renal biopsy in glomerulonephritis: • Presence of acute renal failure or nephrotic syndrome • Absence of evidence of streptococcal infection • Presence of normal complement levels • Persistence of hematuria and proteinuria, diminished renal function, and/or a low C3 level for 
more than 2 months after the disease onset Serum triglycerides (Option A) are elevated in nephrotic syndrome, not in nephritic syndrome. The acute phase generally resolves within 6 to 8 weeks. Although urinary protein excretion and 
hypertension usually normalize by 4-6 wk after onset, microscopic hematuria (Option B) can 
persist for 1 to 2 years after the initial presentation. The serum C3 level (Option C) is significantly reduced in >90% of patients in the acute phase, 
and returns to normal 6-8 weeks after onset.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 6-year-old boy with a previously diagnosed renal disorder is brought to your OPD with the 
following reports for a second opinion. What is the likely diagnosis? 503 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The findings mentioned are characteristic of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Findings in PSGN: 513 
Sold by @itachibot • Light microscopy: Enlarged, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase 
in the mesangial matrix. Polymorphoneutrophil (PMN) infiltration in the early stages. • Immunofluorescence: “Lumpy-bumpy” deposits of immunoglobulin and complement on the 
glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and in the mesangium. • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or “humps,” are observed on the epithelial side of 
the GBM. The image given below depicts the microscopic picture of PSGN. It shows glomerular 
hypercellularity due to intracapillary leukocytes. Neutrophilic infiltration is present and is marked 
with purple hematoxylin stain (black arrows). Other options: Idiopathic rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis: • Light microscopy: Crescents develop in several forms of glomerulonephritis (are a characteristic 
response to the deposition of fibrin in Bowman’s space) • Electron microscopy: No deposits Focal segmental glomerulonephritis: • Light microscopy: Focal sclerotic lesions • Electron microscopy: Foot process fusion Minimal change disease: • Light microscopy: Normal • Electron microscopy Effacement of foot process

questions.question:
Question 8: An 8-year-old boy presented with cola-coloured urine, decreased urine output, and facial 
puffiness for 3 days. He had a history of skin infection 4 weeks back. On examination, he is 
found to be hypertensive. His serum C3 levels are low and ASO levels are increased. What is 
the appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
514 
Sold by @itachibot The features of hematuria, oliguria, facial oedema present with a history of skin infection points 
towards the diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Results of complement 
study and ASO levels also support this diagnosis. Supportive conservative therapy is the best step 
in the management of PSGN. Management of PSGN is directed at treating the acute effects of renal insufficiency (sodium 
restriction and prescribing diuretics - usually with intravenous furosemide) and hypertension. Although a 10-day course of systemic antibiotic therapy with penicillin is recommended to limit 
the spread of the nephritogenic organisms, antibiotic therapy does not a■ect the natural history of 
acute PSGN. Note: Steroids and cyclosporine are not used in the management of PSGN.

questions.question:
Question 9: Sarthak, a 7-year-old boy, was brought to the emergency department by his parents with 
complaints of blurred vision and severe headache since today morning. They mentioned an 
episode of fits 2 hours back following which they rushed him to the hospital. On further 
enquiry, it was elicited that the child had decreased urine output for 5 days with cola coloured 
urine. He was hypertensive with bilateral pitting pedal oedema. The doctor remembered that 
Sarthak has a glomerular disorder warranting him multiple prior ward admissions and his 
existing condition could be a possible complication of the same. All of the following are 
commonly seen as a complication of this disorder except-
questions.explanation:
The given features of oliguria, hematuria, pedal edema and hypertension are likely of 
glomerulonephritis. The complication of hypertensive encephalopathy is seen in this case due to 
symptoms of seizure, blurred vision and severe headache. Hyperkalemia and left ventricular 
failure are also common complications of glomerulonephritis while bleeding diasthesis is not a 
complication of glomerulonephritis. Acute complications of glomerulonephritis result from hypertension and acute renal dysfunction- • Hypertension is seen in 60% of patients and is sometimes associated with hypertensive 
encephalopathy and intracranial bleeding. • Acute renal failure can occur, which may require treatment with dialysis. Other potential complications include the following: • Heart failure • Hyperkalemia • Hyperphosphatemia • Hypocalcemia • Hyponatremia • Acidosis • Seizures • Uremia

questions.question:
Question 10: A 9-year-old boy presents with gross hematuria 2 days after an episode of diarrhoea. The 
serum C3 levels are normal. Light microscopy demonstrates focal and segmental mesangial 
proliferation and increased mesangial matrix in the glomerulus. What is the probable 504 
Sold by @itachibot diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Gross hematuria following a gastrointestinal infection, associated with normal C3 levels, in a 
male patient is suggestive of immunoglobulin A nephropathy (Berger nephropathy). • IgA nephropathy is the most common chronic glomerular disease in children. 515 
Sold by @itachibot • Focal and segmental mesangial proliferation and increased mesangial matrix are seen in the 
glomerulus. • It is characterized by a predominance of IgA within mesangial glomerular deposits in the 
absence of systemic disease. • It is seen more often in males. • Gross hematuria occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal 
infection (in contrast to the long latency period observed in acute post-streptococcal 
glomerulonephritis). • It can be associated with loin pain. • Normal serum levels of C3 in IgA nephropathy (help to distinguish this disorder from PSGN). • Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic value because they are elevated in only a few paediatric 
patients.

questions.question:
Question 11: A child developed dark coloured urine and flank pain 2 days after an upper respiratory tract 
infection. The physician suspects IgA nephropathy. What is the location of cellular injury in 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The location of cellular injury in IgA nephropathy (Berger nephropathy) is the deposition of IgA 
antibodies in the mesangial cell. Mesangial cells are directly exposed to the circulation; therefore, they are affected in diseases 
characterized by the deposition of immune complexes. Mesangial cell diseases: • IgA nephropathy • IgM nephropathy • Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis • Class II lupus nephritis • Diabetic nephropathy Note: In IgA nephropathy gross hematuria often occurs within 1-2 days of onset of an upper 
respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. In contrast, a longer latency period of about 1-2 weeks is 
observed in acute postinfectious glomerulonephritis.

questions.question: Question 12: ANCA-positive , pauci-immune glomerulonephritis include-
questions.explanation:
Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is categorized into 3 distinct 
forms: • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener granulomatosis) • Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly called Churg–Strauss syndrome (CSS) 516 
Sold by @itachibot Kidney biopsies typically demonstrate crescentic glomerulonephritis with little or no immune 
complex deposition. ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) comprises a group of multi-systemic diseases affecting 
small-to-medium-sized vessels. It is characterized by the presence of ANCA with specificity for 
either proteinase-3 (PR3) or myeloperoxidase (MPO). Absence or paucity of immune complex deposits in vessel walls is very characteristic, hence the 
name “pauci-immune vasculitis.”

questions.question:
Question 13: An 8-year-old girl presented with complaints of cough, hemoptysis and swelling of both legs. 
Urinalysis was notable for hematuria and proteinuria. Serum anti-GBM antibodies were 
positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis is Goodpasture disease (anti-GBM antibody disease). Anti–glomerular basement 
membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies are diagnostic. "Goodpasture syndrome" is characterized by pulmonary haemorrhage and glomerulonephritis 
and "Goodpasture disease" is used for those patients with glomerulonephritis, pulmonary 
hemorrhage, and anti-GBM antibodies. It is caused due to autoantibodies directed against type IV 
collagen, which is present in the alveoli and glomerular basement membrane. Currently, the 
preferred term for both conditions is “anti-GBM antibody disease”. Other options along with the pathogenesis of glomerular diseases: • IgA nephropathy- mesangial cell disease due to immune complex deposition • Minimal change disease- epithelial cell disease due to flattening of podocytes

questions.question:
Question 14: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. 
Urine examination reveals hematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Microscopic analysis of his renal 
biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following finding?
questions.explanation:
The boy in this clinical scenario has characteristic features of Henoch–Schonlein purpura (HSP). The renal biopsy in this patient will show mesangial proliferation with mesangial deposition of 
IgA • HSP is a common small-vessel vasculitis in childhood. • It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal 
pain. • About half the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic 
microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis. • The nephritis associated with HSP usually follows the onset of the rash • The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymeric 
immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

questions.question: Question 15: All are features of Alport syndrome except-
questions.explanation:
517 
Sold by @itachibot Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive hearing loss) is a feature of Alport syndrome 
(AS). AS or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease (most have X-linked inheritance) caused by 
mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen, a major component of the basement 
membranes. Clinical features of Alport syndrome: • Hematuria: All patients have asymptomatic microscopic hematuria. Recurrent episodes of gross 
hematuria may be seen 1-2 days after an upper respiratory infection. • Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive) • Ocular abnormalities: anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, corneal erosions • Proteinuria: Progressive proteinuria, often exceeding 1 g/ 24 hrs, is common by the 2nd decade 
of life.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 16-year-old boy presented with dark coloured urine. Urinalysis was notable for macroscopic 
hematuria and heavy proteinuria. His father is a known case of Alport syndrome. What defect 
is responsible for this condition? 506 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
A defect in type IV collagen, a major component of the basement membrane, is responsible for 
Alport syndrome. Alport syndrome is a genetically heterogeneous disease, 85% is X-linked and the rest may be 
autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant.

questions.question:
Question 18: Microalbuminuria is defined as a urinary albumin excretion rate of  
.
questions.explanation:
Microalbuminuria is defined as a urinary albumin excretion rate of 30–300 mg/24 hrs. 518 
Sold by @itachibot Here, the presence of albumin in the urine is above the normal level but below the detectable 
range for the urine-dipstick methods. It is commonly associated with glomerular hyperfiltration 
and blood pressure elevation. In adults, persistent microalbuminuria indicates diabetic nephropathy and is also a predictor of 
cardiovascular and renal disease. In children, microalbuminuria is associated with obesity and predicts the development of diabetic 
nephropathy in type 1 diabetes mellitus.

The currently accepted definitions of “nephrotic range proteinuria” include: • Urine protein: creatinine ratio > 2 • Urine protein > 40 mg/m2/hr • Urine protein 3+ or 4+ in dipstick test As a consequence of the large urinary loss of protein, the patient develops hypoalbuminemia (< 
2.5 g/dL) and gross edema.

questions.question:
Question 20: 507 
Sold by @itachibot It is expected to see all of the following clinical features in a 5-year-old boy with nephrotic 
syndrome except-
questions.explanation:
Hematuria is not a usual feature of nephrotic syndrome. It is a feature of nephritic syndrome. 
However, occasionally it is seen in the FSGS variant of nephrotic syndrome as well. Classic features of nephrotic syndrome: • Nephrotic range proteinuria ( >40mg/m2/hr urine protein: creatinine ratio >2) • Hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL) • Edema • Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol > 200 mg/dL) • Hypercoagulability

questions.question: Question 21: What is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children?
questions.explanation:
The commonest cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease. (85% of 
cases). The glomeruli appear almost normal on microscopy, hence the name. Immunofluorescence 
microscopy are negative, and electron microscopy shows effacement of the epithelial cell foot 
processes. Treatment: Steroids; 95% of patients respond. 519 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: • Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly; it is 
a rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. • Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis: All patients have asymptomatic hematuria; progressive 
proteinuria is common only by the 2nd decade of life and can be severe enough to cause nephrotic 
syndrome. This nephrotic syndrome is not common in children. • IgA nephropathy presents more commonly as an acute nephritic syndrome or with 
asymptomatic hematuria. It presents with nephrotic syndrome quite rarely.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 5-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling around 
the eyes, abdomen and feet for 2 weeks. On investigating, his urine was positive for 4+ 
proteinuria with absent hematuria. A spot urine protein: creatinine ratio was reported to be 
2.5. His serum albumin was 2.3 g/dL and serum creatinine was 0.5 mg/dL. Serum cholesterol 
and triglyceride levels were also elevated. A diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome was concluded. 
Which of the following correctly mentions the aetiology of its most common variant in 
children?
questions.explanation:
Nephrotic syndrome is concluded as the diagnosis here because of the symptoms of anasarca and 
proteinuria. A spot urine protein:creatinine ratio >2, low serum albumin levels, and 
hyperlipidemia marked by high cholesterol and triglyceride levels, further add to this diagnosis. 
Minimal change disease is the commonest cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and 
constitutes 85% of all paediatric cases. The etiology is due to the flattening of foot processes 
(podocytes) of epithelial cells (seen on electron microscopy). This finding is marked in the image 
given below. • Here, the glomeruli appear normal or show a minimal increase in mesangial cells and matrix. • It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. • Epithelial cells, in conjunction with the basement membrane, allow the filtration of plasma 
solutes but block the passage of cells and plasma proteins. Hence, this epithelial cell disease, 
disrupts the filtration barrier, resulting in proteinuria. • More than 95% of children with minimal change disease respond to corticosteroid therapy. Causes of epithelial cell injury: • Minimal change disease 520 
Sold by @itachibot • Membranous nephropathy • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis • Class V lupus nephritis • Diabetic nephropathy

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following is not a cause of hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome?

options.a: Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion
options.b: Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen
options.c: Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S

questions.explanation:
Increased (and not decreased) platelet number and aggregability cause hypercoagulability in 
nephrotic syndrome. Hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome is due to all of the following factors: • Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion • Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen • Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S • Increased platelet number and aggregability

questions.question:
Question 24: A 4-year-old boy presents with facial oedema that has now progressed to total body swelling 
involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and serum 
cholesterol was also elevated. What is the initial treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephrotic 
syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone. Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen 
in ages 2-6 years with a clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome, that is, heavy proteinuria, oedema, 
hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral 
oedema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child 
fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome. They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 
2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the 
next 6-8 weeks is recommended. Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant 
patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows: • Cyclophosphamide • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus • Mycophenolate • Levamisole • Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

questions.question:
Question 25: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after  
 
weeks of corticosteroid therapy.
questions.explanation:
521 
Sold by @itachibot Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome is defined as failure to achieve remission after 6 weeks of 
corticosteroid therapy. According to the latest Indian Society of Pediatric nephrology(ISPN) guidelines, it is defined as 
the absence of remission despite 6-weeks therapy with prednisolone at daily dose of 60mg/m2

questions.question:
Question 26: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OPD for 
vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child?

options.a: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
options.b: All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
options.c: Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
options.d: Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child’s sibling

questions.explanation:
In a child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines can be given. Option A: Live virus vaccines are administered with caution in children receiving corticosteroid 
therapy. They can be given to patients in whom the prednisone dose is below 1mg/kg daily or 
2mg/kg on alternate days. If the patient is receiving corticosteroid-sparing agents 
(cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine), live virus vaccines are contraindicated. Option C: Only live vaccines are contraindicated in this child. Full pneumococcal vaccination (with 
the 13-valent conjugate vaccine and 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine) and influenza vaccination 
can be given annually to the child and their household contacts. Option D: Immunization of siblings/healthy household contacts with live vaccines is necessary to 
reduce the risk of infection transmission to the immunosuppressed child. Direct exposure to the 
gastrointestinal/respiratory secretions of the household contacts is avoided for about 3-6 weeks 
after vaccination. Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It 
is characterized by heavy proteinuria, edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. The 
diagnosis is confirmed by performing a urinalysis and urine protein: creatinine ratio. Nephrotic 
range proteinuria is proteinuria greater than 3.5 g per 24 hours (3+ or 4+) or a urine protein : 
creatinine ratio exceeding 2. The recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome is a daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) 
of prednisolone for 6 weeks followed by an alternate dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 
weeks. Definitions regarding the course of nephrotic syndrome: • Frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome: 2 relapses in 6 months or 3 or more relapses in 12 
months. • Steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome: Relapse during steroid tapering or within 2 weeks of 
discontinuation. • Steroid resistance: Failure to achieve remission despite therapy with daily prednisolone for 6 
weeks Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant 
patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are cyclophosphamide, calcineurin 
inhibitors: cyclosporine and Tacrolimus, mycophenolate, levamisole, and rituximab (a chimeric 
monoclonal antibody against CD20).

questions.question:
Question 27: Congenital nephrotic syndrome is defined as nephrotic syndrome manifesting  
. 509 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: At birth or within 3 months of life
options.c: At birth or within 6 months of life
options.d: At birth or within 1 year of life

questions.explanation:
522 
Sold by @itachibot Congenital nephrotic syndrome is defined as nephrotic syndrome manifesting at birth or within 3 
months of life. It may be • Primary: Due to inherited disorders caused by mutations in NPHS 1, NPHS 2, WT1, or LAMB2. • Secondary: Due to in utero infections like cytomegalovirus infection, toxoplasmosis, syphilis, 
HIV infection, hepatitis B virus or hepatitis C virus HCV infection, infantile systemic lupus 
erythematosus (SLE), or mercury exposure.

questions.question:
Question 28: An 11-year-old boy with a chronic hepatitis B infection develops nephrotic syndrome. What 
would be the most likely pathology encountered in renal biopsy of this child?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the pathology would be membranous nephropathy. 
Membranous nephropathy can be secondarily caused by Hepatitis B infection. Membranous nephropathy: Membranous nephropathy is a rare cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. • It is classified as the primary, idiopathic form, where there is an isolated renal disease, or 
secondary, where nephropathy is associated with other identifiable systemic diseases or 
medications • In children, secondary form is far more common. The most common etiologies of secondary 
form are systemic lupus erythematosus or chronic infections. Among the latter, chronic hepatitis 
B infection and congenital syphilis are the best characterized and recognized causes.

questions.question:
Question 29: Finnish-type congenital nephrotic syndrome is caused by a mutation in the  
 gene.
questions.explanation:
Finnish type congenital nephrotic syndrome is a steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome caused by 
a mutation in the nephrin gene (NPHS 1). • Affected infants usually present at birth with edema caused by massive proteinuria. • They are delivered with a large placenta (>25% of the infant’s weight). • There is severe hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and hypogammaglobulinemia. • Prenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated maternal and amniotic -fetoprotein levels.
